answers.body_markdown:
In short, yes.

Follow the excellent directions at
https://www.reddit.com/r/algotrading/comments/c81vzq/td_ameritrade_api_access_2019_guide/. (Even with them, I spent excessive time on trial and error!)

Since stackoverflow has a limit of 8 links in a response, and the localhost text string looks like a link, I’m showing it with the colon replaced by a semicolon, i.e., http;//localhost to reduce the link count. Sorry.

I used the Chrome browser after first trying Brave, which did not work for, possibly because of my option selections.

Go to https://developer.tdameritrade.com/user/me/apps

Add a new app using http;//localhost (delete existing app if there is one).
Copy the resulting consumer key text string (AKA client_id or OAuth User ID).

Go to https://developer.tdameritrade.com/content/simple-auth-local-apps, follow instructions. Note: leading/trailing blanks were inserted by MSWord due to copy/paste of the auth code, which had to be manually deleted after wasting excessive time identifying the problem. The address string looks like:

https://auth.tdameritrade.com/auth?response_type=code&redirect_uri=http%3A%2F%2Flocalhost&client_id=ConsumerKeyTextString%40AMER.OAUTHAP

This returns a page stating the server refused to connect, but the address bar now contains a VeryLongStringOfCharacters in the address bar:
https;//localhost/?code= VeryLongStringOfCharacters

Copy the contents of the address bar, go to https://www.urldecoder.org/, decode the above, and extract the text after “code=”.  This is your **refresh_token**

Go to: https://developer.tdameritrade.com/authentication/apis/post/token-0, fill out the fields with 

    grant_type=authorization_code
    refresh_token=<<blank>>
    access_type=offline
    code=RefreshTokenTextString
    client_id=ConsumerKeyTextString@AMER.OAUTHAP
    redirect_uri=http;//localhost

Press SEND.

If the resulting page starts with **HTTP/1.1 200 OK**, you have succeeded.

```sql
WITH inserted AS (
  INSERT INTO storecategorycode(isenabled) VALUES(true) 
  RETURNING id
)
INSERT INTO storecategorycodeml 
(storecategorycode_id, category1, category2, category3, category4, category5, lang) 
SELECT id, 'Restaurant','Restaurant-1','Cafe','In-store','takeout','en'
FROM inserted
;

```

This will do the `INSERT` into `storecategorycode` first, then return the `id` value and let you reference it in the subsequent `INSERT`.

answers.body_markdown:
If you have two remotes for you repos `project_a` and `shared_stuff`, then
you can create local branch for `shared_stuff` repo and pull changes to local branch only: `git branch shared_stuff-master shared_stuff/master` (I suppose you will use `master` branch, replace it if not). Then you can [squah merge] shared branch into primary branch and push it to `project_a`:
```bash
git checkout -b shared_stuff-master shared_stuff/master
git pull shared_stuff master
git checkout -b master project_a/master
git merge --no-commit --squash shared_stuff-master
git commit -m "merged changes from shared_stuff"
git push project_a master
```
So you'll not publish references from `shared_stuff` repo to `project_a` repo, only changed files will be published.
answers.title: Git: pull files from remote but do not add to .git/metadata

answers.body_markdown:
I think your problem is both easier and harder than you expect.  It's easier because Git doesn't *store* changes at all.  Git just stores *commits*.  It's harder because you *will* have to get things into (some) Git metadata, somewhere—or else just bypass Git entirely for this particular operation.  Unless you *do* bypass Git entirely for this particular operation, adding entries to `.gitignore` will not be fruitful.

### Behind-the-scenes basics

Let me try to clarify what's going on behind the scenes.  Git's storage system is all about *commits* rather than files.  Each commit *stores* (some set of) files, as a complete snapshot.  Each commit also stores some per-commit metadata: who made it (author and committer), when (two date-and-time-stamps for author and committer), and why (the log message).  Each commit is uniquely identified by its (unique) hash ID.  Each commit *also* stores the unique hash ID(s) of its immediate parent commit or commits.

These hash IDs, stored in each commit and pointing backwards to some earlier commit(s), form the history in a Git repository.  That is, if you've just made a new commit in your repository, on your `master` branch, that new commit has some big ugly hash ID that is unique to it.  Let's call this hash ID `H`.  Inside commit `H` itself, there is a line that says "my parent commit is ______": fill in the blank with the raw hash ID of the commit you had checked out as your `master` before you made the new commit, but let's just call that commit `G` for convenience.  Commit `G`, of course, will have yet another parent-commit hash ID inside it: let's call that `F`.  If every commit is in a nice neat simple line (there are no branches and merges), and we draw them, we get:

    ... <-F <-G <-H

where `H` is the *last* commit in this line.  It points back to its parent `G`, which points back to `F`, and so on, all the way back to the very first commit ever made—which we can call `A`.  Since that's the first commit, it cannot and therefore does not have an earlier commit: it points to nothing else, and is called a *root commit*.

In order to *find* which commit is the *last* one, Git stores the raw hash ID of the last commit under a branch name like `master`.  So the name `master` simply points to commit `H` now:

    ...--F--G--H   <-- master

Just a moment ago, before you made commit `H`, the name `master` pointed to commit `H`.  The act of creating a new commit stores:

 * a new snapshot,
 * with you as the author and committer,
 * "now" as the two date-and-time-stamps,
 * your log message as the log message; and
 * the previous branch-tip-commit as its parent.

The *content* in the new snapshot comes from the index.  What the index stores is not *differences:* it is the *next* commit snapshot, ready to be made.

When you run `git status`, Git runs `git diff` internally, to see what's *different* in the ready-to-make next commit, vs what's in the current commit.  Anything that's *different* here is listed as "changes to be committed"—but they're not *changes*, they are whole files.  At the same time, Git also runs a second `git diff` to compare the index's files to the work-tree's files.  Whatever is *different* here is listed as "changes not staged for commit"—but they're not *changes*, they are whole files.  The work-tree files are just in a form that you can see, and work with.  (The index copies are in a special Git-only form, ready to be committed.)

You have one "main" other Git you call `origin`.  With this Git, you call it up—or rather, have your Git call it up—now and then and your Git compares hash IDs with their Git.  If your Git has hash IDs that they don't have, your Git can give their Git those new commits.  Then, whether or not you gave them new commits, your Git can ask them, e.g., to *please set your `master` to point to commit `H`*.  (For this to work, you must first send them commit `H`.)  They either agree, and now they have new commit `H` and *their* `master` also points to (their copy of) commit `H`, or they say "no, I won't do that for ______" (fill in the blank with the reason).

### How to get what you want

The simplest option is to add a *third* Git repository.  This third Git has no shared commits with your local repository, nor with the Git over at `origin`: your Git and the `origin` Git keep sharing commits, which are uniquely identified by their hash IDs, and which connect to each other through these backwards-pointing links inside each commit.  This third Git has not met your Git before and has all-different hash IDs in *its* history: none of them are the same as any of your commits's IDs (by definition, as all commit hash IDs are unique everywhere unless the commit itself has been shared directly).

So, after you use `git remote add` to add a name and URL for this third Git, you can then run <code>git fetch *name*</code>—use the name you used in the `git remote add` command—to obtain *all* the commits from their Git.  Here I'll use the name `third` (although that's not a very good name).  For simplicity, let's assume you have a grand total of eight commits, which we'll call `A` through `H`, and that they have just three, which we'll call `N`, `O`, and `P`; and that you have one branch name, `master`, and so do they.  Your Git will obtain their three commits so that you now have:

    A--B--C--D--E--F--G--H   <-- master

    N--O--P

Note that none of their commits connect to any of yours, nor vice versa: these are unrelated histories.  Now that you have their three commits, though, your Git needs to create a *name* to remember that `third`'s `master` points to commit `P`.  Your Git will use the name `third/master` (or whatever name you used), so you now have:

    A--B--C--D--E--F--G--H   <-- master, origin/master

    N--O--P   <-- third/master

I added `origin/master` because your Git is presumably remembering that `origin`'s `master` points to commit `H`, too, so your Git now has two of these *remote-tracking names:* `origin/master` remembering `H`, and `third/master` remembering `P`.

The problem now is that you'd like (some) files to come out of commit `P`.  If you just do:

    git checkout third/master

Git will put you in "detached HEAD" mode after:

 * removing all of *your* files from the index and work-tree, and
 * copying all the files from commit `P` into the index and work-tree

which leaves you with none of your files anywhere you can work with them.  You can then:

    git checkout master

to have your Git remove from the index all of `P`'s files, remove them all from the work-tree, and refill the index and your work-tree from `H`'s files.

That's not much help.  Sure, everything is back to the way you need to work with *your* stuff, but you can't see their files!  They're back to being hidden inside commit `P`.  There are several things you *can* do here though, and the most direct one is:

    git checkout third/master -- <paths>

where the `<paths>` arguments tell Git which *files* to extract from commit `P`.  This form of `git checkout` *does not* change your *current commit*, so you will still have your `master`, and therefore commit `H`, checked out.  What it does do instead is extract the named files—including entire directories-full of files, if `<paths>` names some directory or set of directories: all the files in that sub-tree will get extracted—with the contents of the files going into *both* your index *and* your work-tree.

So, if everything you want from commit `P` is in, say, `foo/`, just use:

    git rm -rf foo/
    git checkout third/master -- foo/

and you're ready to commit the updated files: everything in `foo/` has just come out of commit `P`.  The `git rm -rf foo/` step tells Git to delete all of *your* files, which you only need if there are some files in your `foo/` that aren't in commit `P`'s `foo/` (and you want those files to be gone).

If you need to be much more selective—if `foo/` is not sufficient—you might want to:

 * use `git worktree add` to make a new work-tree containing commit `P`, or
 * not use this `third` remote method at all: just clone their repository in some other location, and selectively copy files from that clone into your clone, then `git add` the copied files.

Note that if you use a separate (fourth!) clone, it becomes impossible to accidentally push the `N-O-P` chain of commits from your Git to your Git's `origin`, as they never exist anywhere in your Git.  If you do add a remote named `third`, those extra commits *still* won't go over to `origin` unless you do one of these two things:<sup>1</sup>

 * make some of your own branches use those commits (directly, by pointing to them, or indirectly, by merging the unrelated history into your own commit history), or
 * set one or more of your own local branch names to point to their commit(s)

*and* then `git push` these local branch names to `origin`.  That is, you have to first put `N-O-P` (or any other third-party Git repo commits) *into* your own history, then ask your Git to send your history—your commits—to `origin` and ask their Git to remember one of these new commits under some name (usually, branch name, but any name—branch, tag, whatever—suffices).

---

<sup>1</sup>You can also deliberately send the entire `N-O-P` chain by doing:

    git push origin <hash-of-P>:<name>

where `<name>` is the name you want their (`origin`'s) Git to set after they receive the `N-O-P` chain.  But presumably you won't do that...
answers.title: Git: pull files from remote but do not add to .git/metadata

[![enter image description here][1]][1]

From the image you can see there are two parameters which are being varied for each sub-image. First, the rows are changed by color channel, where the top is the red channel, the middle is the green channel, and the bottom is the blue channel. Wait, why don't the colors look more red, green, and blue, in that order? Because the change you to be making is the ratio, or intensity, or that channel, in relationship to the other channels. We're going to use three different intensities, 0.1 (reduce the channel a lot), 0.5 (reduce the channel in half), and 0.9 (reduce the channel only a little bit).

For instance, a pixel represented as (200, 100, 50) is a sort of burnt orange color. So the top row of changes would create three alternative pixels, varying the first channel (red). one at (20, 100, 50), one at (100, 100, 50), and one at (180, 100, 50). The next row would vary the second channel (blue), and would create pixels of color values (200, 10, 50), (200, 50, 50) and (200, 90, 50).
Note: A font is included for your usage if you would like! It's located in the file readonly/fanwood-webfont.ttf

Starting with version `75` CEF now supports the Chromium Network Service which brings a huge number of breaking API changes.

As per https://github.com/cefsharp/CefSharp/issues/2743

Resource-related callbacks have been moved from `IRequestHandler` to a new `IResourceRequestHandler` interface which is returned via the `IRequestHandler.GetResourceRequestHandler` method


- New [RequestHandler][1] is available to override only the methods you require
- New [ResourceRequestHandler][2] is available to override only the methods you require


  [1]: http://cefsharp.github.io/api/75.1.x/html/T_CefSharp_Handler_RequestHandler.htm
  [2]: http://cefsharp.github.io/api/75.1.x/html/T_CefSharp_Handler_ResourceRequestHandler.htm

There are a number of things you may want to improve / correct in your code.

answers.title: Improve join speed on timestamp range on postgresql

answers.body_markdown:
This is one of the cases where [range types][1] come in handy as they treat NULL values properly.

Create an index on the range:

    CREATE INDEX orders_range ON orders using gist (tsrange(start_time,end_time,'(]'));

Then use the same range definition in the join condition

    SELECT *
    FROM data pd
    JOIN orders o ON pd.timestamp <@ ts_range(o.start_time, o.end_time, '(]')
    WHERE pd.machine_id = 19 
      AND pd.name = 'somevalue' 
      AND pd.timestamp > '2019-09-15 22:00:00' AND pd.timestamp <= '2019-09-22 21:59:59.999'

---

Unrelated, but: I would use `pd.timestamp < '2019-09-22 22:00:00'` instead of a `<=` operator with a timestamp that is a few milliseconds before 22:00:00


  [1]: https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/rangetypes.html

answers.body_markdown:
You need to set `Access-Control-Expose-Headers` in your backend to expose your custom response headers.

Taken from [Mozilla Docs on Access-Control-Expose-Headers](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Headers/Access-Control-Expose-Headers):

> The Access-Control-Expose-Headers response header indicates which headers can be exposed as part of the response by listing their names.

> By default, only the 6 CORS-safelisted response headers are exposed:

> Cache-Control, Content-Language, Content-Type, Expires, Last-Modified, Pragma

> If you want clients to be able to access other headers, you have to list them using the Access-Control-Expose-Headers header.


Therefore, you have to code your backend to set `Access-Control-Expose-Headers` such that it returns: 

`Access-Control-Expose-Headers: x-total-count, x-next-page, x-per-page` 

OR

`Access-Control-Expose-Headers: *`

Here's a simple [stackblitz](https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-6mxxpt) for you to explore, you can observe in the StackBlitz's console that I can retrieve Etag headers but **not** X-Frame-Options because https://api.github.com has set `Access-Contorl-Expose-Headers` to expose Etag but not X-Frame-Options:

[![enter image description here][1]][1]


  [1]: https://i.stack.imgur.com/lglT8.png

Assuming the strings are in Column A and you're only looking for the year 2019 you could use this
    
    =DATE(LEFT(MID(A1,SEARCH(2019,A1),8),4), MID(MID(A1,SEARCH(2019,A1),8),5,2), RIGHT(MID(A1,SEARCH(2019,A1),8),2))
answers.title: extracting date from from string

answers.body_markdown:
Suppose in each string you only have **one 8-digit numerical string** representing the date in the form of `YYYYMMDD` that you want to extract, you can use one of the following three formulas to return the date:

[![Example][1]][1]

**Method 1:**

    =DATE(LEFT(MAX(IFERROR(--MID(A1,ROW($A$1:INDEX($A:$A,LEN(A1))),8),0)),4),MID(MAX(IFERROR(--MID(A1,ROW($A$1:INDEX($A:$A,LEN(A1))),8),0)),5,2),RIGHT(MAX(IFERROR(--MID(A1,ROW($A$1:INDEX($A:$A,LEN(A1))),8),0)),2))

**Method 2:**

    =DATEVALUE(LEFT(MAX(IFERROR(--MID(A1,ROW($A$1:INDEX($A:$A,LEN(A1))),8),0)),4)&"/"&MID(MAX(IFERROR(--MID(A1,ROW($A$1:INDEX($A:$A,LEN(A1))),8),0)),5,2)&"/"&RIGHT(MAX(IFERROR(--MID(A1,ROW($A$1:INDEX($A:$A,LEN(A1))),8),0)),2))

**Method 3:**

    =DATEVALUE(TEXT(MAX(IFERROR(--MID(A1,ROW($A$1:INDEX($A:$A,LEN(A1))),8),0)),"0000-00-00"))

Please note, all methods are using **array formula** so you **MUST** press <kbd>Ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>Shift</kbd>+<kbd>Enter</kbd> upon finishing the formula in the formula bar otherwise they will not function correctly. Then you can simply drag the formula down to apply across.

>The logic is to use this array formula `=MAX(IFERROR(--MID(A1,ROW($A$1:INDEX($A:$A,LEN(A1))),8),0))` to extract the numerical string first. Method 1 & 2 follow the same logic which is to extract the `year YYYY`, `month MM` and `day DD` component from the numerical string and then use use **DATE** or **DATEVALUE** function to return the date. Method 3 is using a formatting trick to quickly turn the numerical value into a text date and then use **DATEVALUE** function to convert the text date into a "real" date.

Let me know if you have any questions. Cheers :)

  [1]: https://i.stack.imgur.com/5rniT.png

answers.body_markdown:
The react-select-dropdown is a bit special indeed. What we do to select a value from a react-select-dropdown is the following:
```js
cy.get('[id*="start-shift-floats"]').click()
cy.get('[id^="react-select-"]')
    .contains('Out-of-Network')
    .click()
```
What you should know about this:
`cy.get('[id*="start-shift-floats"]')` is the actual `get()` to open up the dropdown. So it will be named different in your application.
`cy.get('[id^="react-select-"]')` is the usual `get()` for the options in a react-select-dropdown. By checking it which contains 'Out-of-Network', we can let Cypress click that specific option.

answers.title: How to selectively manage the props of child components from within a parent component?

answers.body_markdown:
Ofcourse. Right now, you have managed the components without state as stateless components. Now make a stateful component to say, when the Home to be rendered : (I Used react hooks as you already have a function component)

Use render props of route to pass props to component like this:

**Option 1 : Use render props**

    const [needsHomeMenu, setNeedsHomeMenu] = useState(false); // you can use this.setState({needsHomeMenu: true}) to achieve.
    .
    .
    .
    <Toolbar displayHome={needsHomeMenu}/> //Toolbar depends on this state
    .
    .
    // update state from within the component that propagates to Toolbar
    <Route path="/category" render={() => (<CategoryPage doesNeedHome={setNeedsHomeMenu} />)} /> 
    

In **CategoryPage.js** , get the prop and on mount , `doesNeedHome(true)`

In **HomePage.js**, `doesNeedHome(false)`. Now , the state changes and updates the Toolbar props and home goes away.


----------


**Option 2:**

Use router props to decide the path location instead of route render in Option 1.
In **CategoryPage.js** and **HomePage.js** , get the prop and on mount , `doesNeedHome(this.props.location.pathname==='/')` or `doesNeedHome(this.props.location.pathname==='/home')`

Rest state update is same as above.

Component needs to be refactored accordingly in diff files.
answers.title: How to selectively manage the props of child components from within a parent component?

answers.body_markdown:
The DateTime type stores a range of dates and times internally as two integers (date part and time part), with the date part holding the number of days before or after 01-01-1900 (negative values for before).

If Microsoft were to change the meaning of 0 (being 01-01-1900) in a future release, it would invalidate the data being stored in the table (as users would see different dates being displayed) - so it will not happen.

If they did need to change the datetime type, they would bring out a new type (say datetime3), but datetime would still be there - for backwards compatibility.

answers.body_markdown:
To be able to achieve your objective, it is important to understand what dialogflow events are: Events allow you to invoke intents based on something that has happened instead of what a user communicates. Dialogflow supports events from several platforms (like Google Assistant, Slack, and more) based on actions users take on those platforms. 

When a user attaches a file or shares location, Kommunicate sends a custom event `KOMMUNICATE_MEDIA_EVENT` to your bot along with the attached file information. To have an `upload intent` respond to the `KOMMUNICATE_MEDIA_EVENT`, follow these steps to create this custom event in your dialogflow bot:

**How to add an event to an intent**

 1. Go to the Events section of the intent. 
 2. Type the name of the event you'd like your intent to respond to (`KOMMUNICATE_MEDIA_EVENT`). 
 3. Press enter. 
 4. Click SAVE.

Also remember to add your response that the bot will deliver to a user when they upload a document.

**References:**

 1. https://cloud.google.com/dialogflow/docs/events-overview
 2. https://docs.kommunicate.io/docs/bot-custom-integration#send-attachments-to-bot
 3. https://cloud.google.com/dialogflow/docs/quick/build-agent

I hope this helps?

You can leverage the [Queue][1] Class in C#. Instead of spawning an new thread for each request I would suggest using a single thread to monitor the queue and call the FileGenerator method to create file. You will also not need to make it async in this case.

So whenever a user access the controller method, it will place the model into queue. The thread which is monitoring the queue will process it whenever it has some models in it.

This is probably a crude way for Queue Management :)

Better way would be to use a standard Queuing Mechanisms MSMQ, but then again depends on the complexity of the application and required scalability.


  [1]: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/api/system.collections.generic.queue-1?view=netframework-4.8

I recommend a combined approach; Services are containerized in a shared server, this provides some level of isolation between the services. While using multiple servers for increasing availability and horizontally scaling.

From my experience this achieves the lowest cost and highest availability.

A good container orchestration system like Kubernetes abstracts this and combines all servers in a one virtual cluster, which simplifies the management of the whole infrastructure. In addition it provides some useful services that benefits this type of architecture, like managing the lifecycle of individual services, load balancing and moving services between nodes in case of hardware failure.

answers.body_markdown:
````
ls -d /test/path/*/ |  cut -d '/' -f 1 | sort -nr
````

Although `cut` won't work the way you intend to use it.

Instead use this:

````
ls -d /test/path/*/ | awk -F'/' '{print $(NF-1)}' | sort -nr
````

Also to avoid nullglob, set this before:

````
shopt -s nullglob
````

So that if no directories exist, it doesn't result into error.

I am not sure about the reason the above command doesn't work on `SliTaz Linux 5.0`, but as discussed, this can be done instead:

````
cd /test/path/ ; ls -d */ | awk -F'/' '{print $(NF-1)}' | sort -nr ; cd "$OLDPWD"
````

or

````
(cd /test/path/ ; ls -d */ | awk -F'/' '{print $(NF-1)}' | sort -nr) 
````

looking at the `manage_operator` ruby block, you should drop the `then` keyword since there is no such keyword in ruby.

change:

    if (manage_operator_flag) then

to:

    if (manage_operator_flag)

and just like you did in `manage_auth` ruby block, add log output within the condition block.

also, you should definitly execute chef-client with higher verbosity and examine the log. you can do that by appending [`--log_level debug` to chef-client][1], that is:

```shell
$ chef-client --log_level debug
```

i would also recommend you to use [`remote_file` resource][2] directly, rather then using `ruby_block` to invoke `remote_file` dynamically (at run\convergance-time)

[1]: https://docs.chef.io/ctl_chef_client.html#options

answers.body_markdown:
The error lies in the line `while low <= high:` and the only exit from that loop being through `L[mid_index] == e`. In your example data, the target element is not within the list. After a few iterations, all of low, high and mid_index will be at the highest number of the list.

Depending on how you want to implement this, you can either return the closest number (15), or throw an error if `low` and `high` are equal.
answers.title: Out of bounds search item in Python binary search implementations

answers.body_markdown:
It's very easy to debug this problem. Just attach a debugger (or use print statements) to see that the root cause for your infinite loop is that after a certain point (when `low` and `high` get close to each other`) nothing in your loop changes.

Let's see a very simplified example: `L = [1, 2]`, `x = 5`. In this case, `low = 1`, `high = 2`, `mid_index = 1`. Inside the loop you'll see that the element is greater than mid, so you'll set `low = mid_index` to 1 and finally `mid_index` to 1. So nothing has changed. You didn't really increment nor `low`, neither `mid_index`, thus the infinite loop. For any `L` not containing `x`, after enough iterations, you'll find this exact scenario inside the loop.

To fix the problem, make sure that for each iteration either `low` or `high` changes. For example, since you already check that the `mid_index` element is not what you're looking for, it's safe to set `low` to `mid_index + 1`.
answers.title: Out of bounds search item in Python binary search implementations
